On Saturday Magnus Carlsen plays for the World Cup gold. On Sunday, he meets Andreas (17) at Norwegian level two.
Magnus Carlsens (28) chess club Offering game starts this weekend Norwegian series game. Already the day after the World Cup finals in fishing chess, Carlsen is in action for his new club.
02 Nov 2019, 09:14 by Sondre Moen Myhre

HÃ˜VIK ODDEN:

While Carlsen will try to turn around a near impossible starting point before the final day of the World Cup final, the young chess talent Andreas Tryggestad is preparing for what will happen the following day.
Less than 24 hours after the World Cup gold is awarded, the 17-year-old meets one of his great role models in the Eastland series.
- I'm very excited. It's very big for me. I've played chess for ten years, so it means a lot to me to play against Carlsen, â€says Tryggestad when Aftenposten meets him at Henie Onstad Cultural Center on the way to the World Cup finals.

READ MORE: Carlsen opponent hates memorizing moves, uses Wikipedia to prepare and fears for chess future



Andreas Tryggestad (17) looks forward to playing against Magnus Carlsen.ğŸ“· Sondre Moen Myhre

Coach with Carlsen on the walls
As Carlsen did in his day, Tryggestad runs the chess line at Norway's Top Sports Gymnasium in BÃ¦rum.
- You notice that Carlsen has gone to school, he says.
- The room we practice in is actually called the "Magnus room". There are pictures of Carlsen on the wall.
Throughout the school he trains around ten hours a week in the "Magnus room".
The 17-year-old lives on Nordstrand, a three-hour commute to and from school, and estimates that he spends a total of almost 30 hours a week on chess.
"It's been a lot more this week," he admits.

Fact: This is how Carlsen can still win the World Cup

Magnus Carlsen - Wesley So 1.5 - 10.5


First to 12.5 points wins the World Cup.
In theory, Saturday is played four fast chess games and four light chess games. If it looks the same, it will be decided by armageddon.
Victory in quick chess gives two points. Victory in lightning chess gives one point. When referring, the points are divided between the players.
A total of 12 points can be awarded on Saturday.
So need only 2 points to win the World Cup gold.
Carlsen, for his part, must take at least 11 out of 12 points to secure the gold. If he takes 10.5 of the 12 points, it will be replayed at armageddon.




In 2014, Andreas Tryggestad (t.v.) was among the welcome committee when Magnus Carlsen landed on Norwegian soil after winning the World Cup in classic chess for the second time against Viswanathan "Vishy" Anand.ğŸ“· Heiko Junge / NTB scanpix

The Carlsen Club will assert itself in Europe
Usually Tryggestad plays on the elite series team Nordstrand, but this weekend he takes the trip down to the second team just to get the opportunity to meet Carlsen.
Starting from Norwegian level two, the club Carlsen was instrumental in establishing this summer, Offerspill, his pursuit of both national and international titles.
- We have big plans to become the best in Norway. But we think bigger than that: To be fighting in the top of Europe. That is the goal we are aiming for, says team leader in Offering Game Johannes Luangtep Kvisla.
Carlsen himself states that the club is not just for the top players.
- We want to be a club for everyone. Everything from those who have played chess online and want to find a club where they can find people at their level, to the greatest talents we have in Norway, says Carlsen.


Already on Sunday, Carlsen is in action for his new club Offering Games. First, he will try for the "impossible": to bring in Wesley Sos's nine-point lead in the World Cup in fishing chess.ğŸ“· Fredrik Hagen / NTB scanpix

Have studied Carlsen parties
One of them he meets on Sunday.
With the rating 2365, Tryggestad is the second best ranked Norwegian player of its age class. This means, among other things, that he is one rating point ahead of NRK expert and chess columnist in Aftenposten, Atle GrÃ¸nn.
Still, it's still a long way up to the world's highest-ranked chess player: Magnus Carlsen with his 2870.
- He is obviously much better than me, so I am very likely to lose. But I look at it as very fun, it's a great experience. No matter how it goes I think I can take a lot of lessons and use it further, says Tryggestad.
But he has in no way intended to give up without a fight, and already a few days before his biggest chess game in life he has made a small battle plan.
- I have looked at his last parties and I have an idea of what might happen. It is important for me to prepare well. He's a bit like playing against a computer. He can play anything. Most have some openings they play a lot, but he has everything. So it's not that easy.
First, he hopes Carlsen will perform one of the turnaround operations on the last day of the World Cup in fish chess against Wesley So.
